name: Grand Portage
description: A crucial trading post where Ojibwe people exchanged Asemaa and other goods with French voyageurs.
historicalSignificance: Major gathering point for Native American and European traders, particularly important for tobacco trade routes.

name: Madeline Island
description: Sacred location where Ojibwe people cultivated and traded Asemaa among different bands.
historicalSignificance: Spiritual center for Ojibwe people and key location for traditional tobacco cultivation.

name: Sault Ste. Marie
description: Historic meeting point where multiple tribes gathered to trade Asemaa and other sacred medicines.
historicalSignificance: One of the oldest settlements in the Great Lakes region, crucial for inter-tribal trade.

name: Manitoulin Island
description: Traditional growing grounds for Asemaa, considered sacred by many First Nations.
historicalSignificance: Largest freshwater island in the world, significant spiritual site for tobacco cultivation.

name: Mackinac Island
description: Strategic trading post where Asemaa was exchanged between various tribes and European traders.
historicalSignificance: Key location for fur trade and diplomatic relations between tribes and Europeans.

name: Fond du Lac
description: Important Ojibwe settlement where traditional tobacco cultivation techniques were preserved.
historicalSignificance: Center for maintaining traditional agricultural practices and seed preservation.

name: Red Lake
description: Sacred location where specific strains of Asemaa were cultivated and protected.
historicalSignificance: Home to unique varieties of traditional tobacco preserved through generations.

name: Thunder Bay
description: Major trading hub where Asemaa was exchanged between northern and southern tribes.
historicalSignificance: Critical point for north-south trade routes and cultural exchange.

name: Leech Lake
description: Traditional growing area where specific ceremonial tobacco varieties were maintained.
historicalSignificance: Known for preserving ancient tobacco cultivation methods and ceremonies.

name: Rainy River
description: Important waterway where Asemaa trade routes connected different regions.
historicalSignificance: Crucial water route for tobacco trade between Lake of the Woods and Lake Superior.

name: White Earth
description: Sacred location where traditional tobacco growing knowledge was passed down.
historicalSignificance: Center for preserving traditional ecological knowledge about tobacco cultivation.
